author: he852100
body:
I didn't find a way to use it, how do I use it   

I tried the following method, which returns an error prompt
```powershell
PS /> Enter-PSSession -HostName [0::0] -UserName administrator   
PS /> Enter-PSSession -hostname administrator@[0::0]
PS /> Enter-PSSession -hostname administrator@[0::0]
PS /> Enter-PSSession -hostname administrator@0::0
```
```powershell
Name                           Value                            ----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0-preview.5                  PSEdition                      Core                             GitCommitId                    7.0.0-preview.5
OS                             Linux 4.9.112-perf #1 SMP PREEM… Platform                       Unix
```
```sh
$ ssh administrator@0::0 -i /root/.ssh/winid
Warning: Identity file /root/.ssh/winid not accessible: Permission denied.
Microsoft Windows [版本 10.0.17763.379]
(c) 2018 Microsoft Corporation。保留所有权利。

administrator@WIN-7A2JPVLSMPD C:\Users\Administrator>
```

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: The square brackets are required for PowerShell (and .NET) to understand it's a ipv6 address, but this is passed directly to ssh which doesn't expect it.  Will have a fix soon.

comments.author: msftbot[bot]
comments.body:
:tada:This issue was addressed in #10968, which has now been successfully released as `v7.0.0-preview.6`.:tada:

Handy links:
* [Release Notes](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/tag/v7.0.0-preview.6)

comments.author: he852100
comments.body:
@SteveL-MSFT  Thanks.

Now it is missing a switch。
```powershell
New-PSSession test.com -ipv4 or -ipv6
enter-PSSession test.com ...
irm test.com ...
iwr test.com ...
```

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @he852100 if there is a need to specifically use ipv6 or ipv4, please open a new issue to discuss that.  Thanks!

title: [Support Question]Does it support ipv6?
